content.text:
This two-year-old boy was brought to CHP with 3-week history of occipital headaches. The mother tells you he sleeps with his neck extended. During the last week prior to presenting to CHP he vomited once/day. On neurologic exam there was no noticeable weakness, gait abnormality, balance or visual changes. The mass lesion is partially resected. Your diagnosis? <image 1> <image 2>

A. Pilocytic astrocytoma
B. Subependymoma
C. Glioblastoma
D. Anaplastic ependymoma
E. Medulloblastoma

The images provided are MRI scans of the brain. The first image is a transverse (ax axial) view, and the second image is a sagittal view. The mass lesion in the transverse view appears to be located in the posterior fossa, which is consistent with a posterior fossa tumor. The mass lesion in the sagittal view appears to be located in the cerebellum, which is also consistent with a posterior fossa tumor.

Given the location and appearance of the mass lesion, the most likely diagnosis is:

E. Medulloblastoma

Medulloblastoma is a type of brain tumor that typically arises in the cerebellum and is common in children. It is characterized by a mass lesion that can cause symptoms such as headaches, vomiting, and neurological deficits.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
